description.text:
This is multi-use base for Tiny whoop gates that can be set on the floor, mounted to a wall with suction cups or hooks, and even mounted inverted from a ceiling or rope line. It has an open compartment to hold a 3 cell 1300 ish battery and is designed for the 1/2inch tubing with LED strips inserted that are popular and cheap to make. I used 4ft and 5 foot sections of tubing to make the 'hoop' and simply inserted each end of the piece into the base. The base also has a slot inside of the tube to allow wiring to go through into the battery compartment, it will print typically with support material and should be cleared carefully with a knife.

Mine have been working quite well, hope it's useful!

description.text:
The Raspberry Pi Zero is an amazing device packing a lot of capability into a $5 purchase. But the Zero does not come with the GPIO pins installed, leaving the installation up to the purchaser (that be you). I found soldering the pins more difficult that it should. I could never keep the pins steady while I soldered and balanced the Pi. Thus this "thing" was created. The Raspberry Pi Zero Soldering Holder will secure your Pi while you solder the missing GPIO pins.

It is designed to hold your Pi exactly 8.2 mm above the bottom plate. The pins rest securely in a small box assuring the correct alignment with the Pi.

comments.text: Nice soldering aid. Please don't take this the wrong way but before you solder your next Pi Zero have a look on youtube for some tips. The following link should get you going. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8N18lIL3Uwk

comments.text: Yea I was thinking ... should I show my crappy soldering job?  Thanks for the video!
comments.author: DrJekyll

comments.text: Not trying to be insulting, so don't take this the wrong way, but those are all cold solders. Get some non-lead-free solder with a rosin core -- lead-free is a lot harder to solder with, and a rosin core (the label should read "rosin mildly active" or "RMA" or similar) helps further with getting the solder to properly flow onto the metal elements.

comments.text: Thanks! No offense at all.  I appreciate the help.  This was my first solder attempt in 25+ years.

description.text: Virginia class SSN fast attack submarine.

This is my first submission -- trying to give back after discovering so much cool stuff here.

This is a simple cabinet / drawer knob for your bathroom or laundry room or kitchen or garage or wherever. It is designed to be used with a standard, off-the-shelf #8-32 round head machine screw & nut combo that you can find in any hardware store. You can pre-measure and purchase appropriate length screws, or buy long ones and cut them down as needed with a bolt-cutter or saw. To secure the nut in place, barely thread a nut onto a screw, then guide the nut down into the knob, and move perpendicularly to lock into place. You can then unthread the screw and install as you would any other knob. I had originally planned to design a separate insertable shim to secure the nut in place, but after printing and installing a couple of these knobs, they install pretty securely and the shim doesn't seem necessary.

It will not be visible after printing is complete, but there is an open space behind a very thin layer of material behind the nut, which can accommodate a good amount of excess screw length. The extra space is visible in the above "x-ray" view. This space provides some built-in tolerance if your screw is too long; as you install, your screw will easily break through the thin plastic and occupy the space behind the nut.

The thin layer of material behind the nut was necessary to be able to print the knob with the nut installation port down. That way, with the front-facing side of the knob facing up, you can modify the top surface to include text or a design of your choice. I'm planning to design a raised monogram on the front face of the knob to be printed in a contrast color (see last image above).

Anyhow, I hope the design proves useful if you're looking for a simple knob, feel free to leave any comments, questions or feedback.

description.text:
Miter Slot T-Nut for Table Saw or other tool with similar "T" slots

These are probably (most likely) going to fail if you tighten them toooo much.
But they should stay in place with minimal torque on the bolt / nut.
I printed them with really thick walls / top and bottom - see printer settings below.

Designed for:
1/4" x 20 Hex Nut or Bolt
3/4" Miter Slot with wider bottom groove

Dimensions of Miter Slot on my Table Saw (Rigid TS3650):
Overall Height: .42"
Upper Slot width: .759"
Lower Slot Width: .95"
Lower Slot Height: .157"

Top of T-Nut sits just shy from the top of the table for clamping / tightening.
T-Nut (as designed in my saw) has very little slop or play but moves freely in slot.
Hex nut or bolt fits very snug... no glue needed.

Print settings are what I hope makes for a fairly strong part

medium

comments.text:
today i did a test print of the sFH-18 at 28mm scale (scaled 1.786 times). it went incredibly well,aside from the fact that i printed the wheels partly outside the printers bed (which had nothing to do with the model anyway). I am now reprinting the wheels but all in all this was a perfectly nice print! Some of meshmixer's generated support will be tricky to remove but that's to be expected with a complex model such as this. Overall i really like it though i mush admit one thing,
After having printed multiple artillery pieces i must admit wondering how hard it would be to make the actual gun a seperate piece, thus allowing us to set the elevation ourselves?
Anyway, thanks for your designs!
comments.author: hendrikdc

comments.text: Sorry for the late comment. For guns like the lefh 18 the sig33 and possibly the nebels that wouldn't be very hard however the morser and the sfh18 have hydraulic/pneumatic pistons that extend/shrink when the gun is raised/lowered. So just making the gun separate does not really allow you to put a custom elevation because the pistons would not change.
comments.author: hendrikdc

comments.text:
Couple of things that may be of help in making these guns better, I think the wheels on the early Lefh 18 105mm Howitzer are to small if you look at a few photos on google you'll see that the top of the wheel should come level with the top of the level gun barrel that is why the gun shield has notches at the sides also there were two main types of pressed steel wheels one as shown and one with a central boss. A number of different wooden spoked wheels were used when horse drawn. I think it would be good if they could be printed all the guns in limbered mode as well as they need to be moved across the wargames table to a firing position this would needs including any limber wheels as with the bigger guns. The pressed steel wheels on the late Lefh 18 also have a problem, on all the photos I can find the wheels have five pointed spokes not six.
Why are the wheels on the Sfh18 & k18 chamfered, on all the photos I've seen they are not and also they have only eight holes as on the one shown above.

title: Arduino Uno Boblight Case with 3.5mm Jack

description.text:
A case for my Arduino UNO powered TV backlight setup.

The Arduino is being powered by USB so the female barrel connector is covered. The only exposed connection to the Arduino is the USB.

Standoffs for the Arduino fit M3 sized screws which thread in nicely.

The other hole is for a 3.5mm jack like this that is inset so the threads are long enough and the nut is flush. The 3.5mm jack is used to run data to the WS2801 LED strand.

The lid is friction fit with tabs.

Printed dimensions are 26x86x86mm. Both case and lid had to be rotated in Cura for slicing.

I printed this with 1.2mm walls, but it took forever and had a tiny bit of infill between the inner and outer walls. It probably doesn't need walls that thick but it feels extremely sturdy and has some decent weight to it.

The tutorial used for the electronics is from this adafruit tutorial.

ID Holder for Retractable Lanyards. To assemble: Glue the 2 main pieces together, after they dry, insert up to 2 cards, insert the top filler piece (no glue), then push the keeper pin through all the holes (it's tight so get it aligned well first). This will keep your cards secure. You can then remove the pin and filler piece to remove/replace the cards.

I couldn't find an ID holder that I liked. I wanted to consolidate my cards but not have them flapping all around. I actually stuffed 3 cards in mine, my PATH card in the center (since I never need to get it out or see it) and my work ID and Building ID on the outsides for showing.

comments.text: If yours is seen as much as my ID holder is, You could Probably sell these.  I have gotten SO MANY people asking me if I would make them one, or if I could sell them one.

comments.text:
For glue, use Superglue, and place small dabs around the edge... not too much, to make sure it doesn't squeeze out.
Then I suggest putting something heavy on it for a few hrs to make sure it dries well.. or use binder clips to squeeze the 2 halves together.
Leave out the top pieces until the glue is dry to avoid them accidentally getting glued in place.

comments.text: So, I've done some digging, and ShivInteger is apparently the creation of Matthew Plummer-Fernandez and Julien Deswaef. They created a program that randomly mixes other people's work together and posts it to thingiverse. All the authors whose work has been forcibly integraged get an email saying that their work has been remixed, only to find that the result was something far less useful or artistic than the individual parts.  It had been announced that ShivInteger was dead (in the sense that it was no longer posting such "things"), but apparently that is not the case.
comments.author: mccand

comments.text: Well said. Please remove your BOT art from our platform. Please contribute with your art. If you made these objects by hand I would feel very differently.
comments.author: mccand

Print upside-down, like shown in the preview. No supports needed. I strongly advise to print multiple knobs at once to allow for sufficient cooling of the layers.

Made for this specific potentiometer:

https://www.conrad.de/de/leitplastik-potentiometer-mono-50-k-tt-electronics-ab-p160kn-0fc20-b-50-kr-1-st-452798.html

(Or equivalent 6mm shaft potentiometers)

You might want to fiddle around with the settings in the scad file; they are dialled in for my (quite worn out) Kossel printer using Slic3r. It took a few iterations.

A project enclosure box for electronics. I needed this for a voltage and amperage display monitoring the load on a power supply as well as serving as a junction box. I have included both boxes as someone may find the junction box with the holes precut useful for their own purpose.

Both snap fit and screw fit, so you can have easy access while diagnosing, and then you can secure it when good to go. I was unable to find a project box around this size that was both snap fit and also could be screwed shut, so 3d print it, I did.

You should know that the lid is reduced in size by 1% (Effectively 1mm), to compensate for inaccuracies in my printer. If you have a very precisely calibrated printer so you would rather have the lid perfectly sized, just scale the lid up to 101.1%. I assume this would cause a lid too large for the box for most people, so the 1mm extra tolerance is default.

description.text:
Ok, this is something, I think only Star Wars RP-Gamers and/or those who know wookieepedia back- and forwards will recognize.
The Helix Interceptor by Arakyd Industries.
More info here: http://starwars.wikia.com/wiki/Helix-class_light_interceptor

I stumbled over this ship years ago when I was looking for alternative designs. And ever since then, I was planning to rebuild it.
Now that I have the ability to create something like this at CAD, well, you can imagine it.

Scale 1:270 to fit to the other X-Wing models in my show case
The pin hole is designed for the huge craft base from FFG X-Wing

basically it is done but I'm still 100% satisfied with it so expect some changes.

supplemental entry: updated to version 0.09
some additional hull structures

supplemental entry: updated to version 0.10
Lounge-area enlarged, changed some transitions, added smaller parts for easier printing (at least for the printer I used to get my parts from)

supplemental entry: added reconstructed printparts
And I guess, this will be the last edit on this for some time.

title: Tevo Tarantula Dual Z / Adjustable Z Limit Switch

description.text:
A simple and minimal inverted single-motor dual Z mod for Tevo Tarantula. It's easy to print and effective.

  • Before assembling, make sure both rods (lead screws) are straight. If not, it's better to buy new rods rather than compensating for it or resorting to suboptimal solutions.
  • Key to zero rotational backlash is to properly tighten the belt by adjusting/sliding the secondary rod.

The calibration cube was printed @0.1mm layer height with properly tensioned belts https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1780636

I tried to fix the following problems in the original design:

  1. The X axis can be pushed up and down, which can be problematic especially for auto bed leveling with constant z motion. This is due to the flexible coupler and the bending of the acrylic mount of the Z motor. This design inverts the placement of the motor, which allows the lead screw to sit directly on the motor shaft inside the coupler. This completely prevents any downward push and get rid of the top acrylic bending problem.
  2. Both rods are locked in place with pillow block bearings, which prevent the x axis from rotating like in the original single rod setup. I prefer the single motor solution because the two rods are always in-sync and I can manually turn the z motor without resyncing.
  3. An adjustable z axis limit for quick fine-tuning the height.
  4. Both rods are positioned much closer to the X axis (Photo 4) to reduce the bending torque exerted on the top rod mount (or the original acrylic motor mount). And the top rod mounts are reinforced so that there is minimal or no bending.
  5. The nut mount design allows the x axis to rigidly sit directly on the brass nut of the lead screw to prevent any bending torque and vibration (Photo 4). Both 4 and 5 help prevent banding.

Part list:

  1. 400mm Lead screw. http://www.ebay.com/itm/322001200138
  2. GT2 Timing belt 696mm. http://www.ebay.com/itm/2GT-Timing-Belt-L-520-540-550-600-606-610-640-670-696-GT2-synchronous-Belt-loop-/331976368563
  3. Flange Bearing Pillow. http://www.ebay.com/itm/1Pair-8mm-Bore-Diameter-KFL08-Pillow-Block-Bearing-Flange-Rhombic-Bearings-New-/232076410895?hash=item3608d5000f:g:KtMAAOSwxg5X0ndu
  4. Timing pulley Bore8 OD16. http://www.ebay.com/itm/5PCS-lot-GT2-Timing-Pulley-20T-5-8mm-Bore-FOR-6mm-Belt-Reprap-3D-printer-CNC-/131816900256?var=&hash=item1eb0e646a0:m:mN8y5RI51dnaKfVrGeEKEyA
  5. M3 T nuts. **This is M3 not M4. http://www.ebay.com/itm/50-x-20-Series-European-T-slot-Aluminum-Profile-Carbon-Steel-Drop-In-M3-T-Nuts-/152016284528?hash=item2364e06b70:g:cucAAOSwhMFXkzEX
  6. M3 screws, M4 screws, M4 nuts.

I attached the original fusion 360 file for educational / modification purposes (please excuse the mess) E.g. you may want to change the hole to fit M4 with M4 T nuts instead.

comments.text: I tried for 3 weeks to get this to work without issues, and I just couldn't do it. I leveled the entire printer, made sure it was perfectly level / square, Checked that the rods were perfectly parallel to each other / the printer. Every time I tightened the screws to where the lead screws connect to the X-Axis, the motor would have issues. Sometimes at the top, sometimes in the middle, sometimes at the bottom. I tried spacing them with washers, that didn't work, I tried solid couplers, those didn't work. I was able to get a few decent quality prints out of the whole thing if I loosened the x-axis connections up a little bit, but there were still occasional issues. Not to mention, with the pillow bearings at the top, getting tension across the system that wouldn't pull the lead screws was incredibly difficult.

description.text:
This is a quick design I've done for a Rain Gauge that can be run from a micro controller such as an ESP8266. The parts uploaded here should be all the mechanical bits required. Adding a small magnet to the middle of the bucket would allow it to be read from a read-relay. Only thing that's left is to do is measure the volume in milliliters (or the unit of your choice) and then increment that rainfall count by that much every time the bucket flops over to the other side.

Note, I have not printed any part of this model yet, but I have validated that it should be printable. Would love to see if anyone prints this model. (I just have to many other projects on the go at the moment to spend more time on this right now).

There should be enough space inside to add an ESP8266 and a couple of batteries or run a cable from the read relay indoors. I left this bit of detail up to you. Just make sure your funnel/collector is waterproof enough to keep electronics underneath it dry.

Hope this is interesting and/or useful to someone. ;-)

Comments would be much appreciated.

Updated based on cbergthold's comments:
I've added Base v2.1.stl which raises the bucket a couple of millimeters higher, allowing it to tip a little more. It also now includes two spillways to get the water out of the base easier.
I've added Bucket v2.2.stl which is half the size to allow for more frequent tipping and to fit into the spillways.

update 2
I've made the spillways more printable so that supports are not required and also made the stands for the bucket a bit closer together (while still leaving space for a washer or two) so that the sensor can also be placed closer.

update 3
I added Outer Body sheet.dxf. The idea being that it would be quite a long print to print the outer body. These dimensions should allow you to cut out a flat piece of ABS (1.75-2mm thick) and then ABS weld the edges together to make the outer body in much less time that it would take to print this relatively simple shape.

Update 4.
Looks like the latest bucket does not gather enough water to tip it over. I'm working on an optimal design that needs the least amount of water while still being able to tip the bucket.

Update 5
Have a look at Bucket 2.5. I would apreciate feedback as I have not had time to print it.

Notes:

I was thinking that if the base was printed with a very low infil and filled with something heavy like playsand before the top layer is added it would give the entire thing enough weight to be relatively stable outside in the wind too.

Hello
I really like the idea how to measure the rain by this simple design.
After thinking about this measurement principle, I think a Improvement which reduces the amount of movable parts is to use the mechanism of the Pythagorean Cup.
So you have water pulses to measure.
This can been done with two electrodes, a high resistor and a Schmitt Trigger.
I have not tried it yet but the idea could work.
comments.author: AndreasG4r

comments.text:
Hi AndreasG4r,
Thanks for the idea. This is effectively a syphon which activates after the water has reached a given depth. I think this might have the same problem as the standard bucket in that you would need some minimum amount of water before the first "count" can occur. Just as with the bucket needing a certain amount of water before it is heavy enough for the bucket to tip, you would need a the water to exceed a certain depth before the syphon would activate. The issue here is to make this minimum amount of water as small as possible to give the rain gauge the maximum "resolution". At these levels, unfortunately, you come up against water surface tension exceeding the power of gravity.
comments.author: AndreasG4r

comments.text:
I have some additional ideas how the resolution can be improved.
One is to use multiple measurement cells in series.
So the wather coming from the first measurement unit gets limited by a small hole and runns to a second measurement unit.
When the measurement units are not syncroniced you get more impulses and so you improve your accuracy.
To prevent from synchronisation it is important to chose different measurement volumes with no common multiple.
For example V1/11=V2/13=V3/17
So it's possible to mix syphons and this measurement cell.
comments.author: gineer

comments.text: The problem is not so much with measuring small changes, but rather to have something happen that can be measured. In your idea above, I could easily measure the smallest of those syphons, if you could just make it work.
comments.author: AndreasG4r

comments.text:
As you mentioned the water surface tension is the limitation of the minimum water amount.
I can imagine that a good calibrated bucket gets an higher resolution but the problem is that moving parts can wear out or get stuck.
But also the siphon can get clogged if the diameter is to small.
To be honest, i have no idea whats the best way to determine the amount of water.
comments.author: gineer

comments.text: Hi,

description.text:
I am using the 713Maker Gantry kit which changes the Y end-stops. This bracket mounts the Y end-stop off the left rear 2020upright. V1 was made out of PLA and last pic showing on the build plate. Trimmed it down for V2 and made from PETG.

Was designed for the optical variety of end stop. But works with the mechanical, just a tad close on the PCB lead cutout. Trim off the flag for mechanical endstops.

Update: Gantry Flag model is complete!. The optical Endstops I purchased required inverting the logic in firmware as they were showing triggered when sensors were unblocked, and open when blocked. Very repeatable positioning. Within one step. :D Happy Dance!

Update: Uploaded end cap version for mechanical end stops. Don't need to clip off the flag and there is a nice wide flat spot for the switch to trigger on.

Gantry End has support built-in for the flag. Place FT5 on the print bed and it will print like a champ! Parts built for 0.4 nozzle. Should slice fine with default extrusion width 0.4mm.

Printer:

Folger Tech FT-5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Gantry End has support built-in for the flag. Place FT5 on the print bed and it will print like a champ! Parts built for 0.4 nozzle. Should slice fine with default extrusion width 0.4mm.

comments.text: You said this goes on the back left...it appears like if I use this the limit switch will make contact with the 713 gantry X pulley?
comments.author: LePaul

comments.text: The end cap is proud of the pulley and protects it from contact on three sides. If you use optical limit switches, the flag triggers the switch well before contact with the end cap. If you use mechanical switches, trim off the flag and the switch contacts the end cap. Slide the switch brace up or down to contact a spot on the top shelf, around where the flag was. I can put up a copy of the end cap with no flag and a flat spot for mechanical limit switches if you need. But I used mine 'as is' (with flag removed with side cutters) for a few weeks till my opticals came in. Hope that helps.

comments.author: glassy

print_settings.Notes:: Remember to print hot enough (+200C) for the layers to adhere properly!

description.text:
My modular X-carriage with all the blower fans would crash into the original PCB if I let it run the full 20cm, and I couldn't find a ready-made offset-mount-thingy here, so!

Here's a mount to offset your PCB from it's default spot on the 2040 frame. The offset is customizable in the Customizer app, but an STL with 30/30 X/Z offset (as pictured) is included.

The holes are made for the TEVO Tarantula i3 PCB mount and may not mesh with different models - download the .scad and adjust it to your needs or message me, even!

(Please don't mind the missing screws, I was running low.)

Printer:

TEVO Tarantula i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

+30%

Notes:

Remember to print hot enough (+200C) for the layers to adhere properly!

comments.text: Great idea. Just one issue: what length bolts do I use with the T-nuts to secure to the profile?
comments.author: ironval

comments.text: I used the small... M4s? that came with the TEVO, 13.5mm from head to toe, ~9.6mm thread. I'm not sure if I calculated it, but the bolts don't scrape against the 2020.

title: Belted Extruder v.3 60T Gear with Detachable Handle

description.text:
Designed for use with the Belted Extruder v.3 of dintid here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1764551

Used with an appropriate length of M3 screw and nut.

Attention

Please unplug the E motor socket while winding back or forth the filament to avoid the possible bad effect of current produced by the motor to the RAMPS or other electronical components.

comments.text:
Well done ! I had the same idea a while ago : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1579394 ;)
But my crank is not removable...
comments.author: J-Max

comments.text: Nice design! I'll definitely try it in another of my custom made printer :)
comments.author: J-Max

comments.text: You just made an overweight, overcomplicated extruder  more complicated ! OK, the plastic gear is lighter than the Al but with the handle ? As for the quality ????
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: Handle is detachable. You can remove it if you don't need it. So the plastic gear alone is lighter, as you mentioned. And there is no overweight, no overcomplicated extruder ;)
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
It weights at least as much as a direct extruder, is a lot bigger, clumsier, more parts, screws etc for NO ADVANTAGE at all !
You compare to a Wade extruder and claim it is better. Of course, the Wade is from an other time when not much was available. One can do far better now.
comments.author: s3rkan

comments.text:
I haven't tried another design except this one and classic Wades Extruder. In Wade's extruder, you can push or pull the filament easily through the hole and tube. But in this design I realized that there is not much space for the filament to pass near the "teeth" of the hobbed bolt even if you open the idler. So it is hard to push (or pull) the filament without damaging it. Thus, you can only change the filament by turning the gear. Turning the gear with bare hand... Do you think it is easy? It is not! Also it takes forever to change the filament in this way.
In short, please build this extruder and try to change filament. You'll see the reason of the "crank"...
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
OK so because of these problems, you put a crank.
Why not throw away everything and make a simpler, better direct extruder then ?
To change the filament, I just turn on the hot end which I hope you do too, then retract, put the new one then extrude 20mm to engage it.
Took me more time to write then to do !
comments.author: s3rkan

comments.text: Because I like Bowden :)
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
The Bowden system is used when the extruder is too heavy to be put on the carriage. It is a pain otherwise and offers no advantage at all for a single extruder system.
Anyway for a Bowden extruder there is ABSOLUTELY no reason to use anything else but a DIRECT SIMPLE HANDY extruder because the weight is not an issue ! Geared extruder permits to use a smaller lighter motor to gain weight. Of course if the gears etc... are heavier than the weight saved on the motor, it is worthless. Here this geared extruder (pulleys and belt in fact) is a good example of this.
comments.author: s3rkan

description.text: The Assistive Key holder product, as it says in the name is a type of Swiss army key holder. This product allows different types and sizes of keys to be put together in the two shells and all you have to do is slide out the key just like you do when using a Swiss army knife set and gripping on to the rest of the support material you can open and close doors/locks and other sorts of things that require a key to open it and then just slide the key back in when done. In addition, the keys have to be well fixed in the holes using specifically the M3 bolts, nuts and washers to assemble and these M3 bolts, nuts and washers are to be bought separately. It allows a range of keys to be put be put together, so depending on the dimensions of your keys it will also depend how many keys will fit in it. This product initially was made to help people with Arthritis but can be used by people that have weak muscles/joints or even people that just find the product helpful and useful. This product basically helps people in two main ways, which is to provide enough support material to hold on to when trying to open the door and turning the keys in the lock as sometimes it requires a lot of strength to open, so this product helps in restoring energy and preventing you from using a lot of strength which is why it's perfect for people with Arthritis and other diseases that have to do with muscle and joint weakness. The second reason is that this product helps you keep all your keys together in one bunch and well organized rather than all of the place in your bag/purse and later you having to look for it when you can just have it all organized in one place. This assistive product helps people become more independent and efficient instead of having to ask other people for help especially if you have any type of disease which prevents you from doing things alone.

author: ninharp

description.text:
Regular rails for Eurorack Modular Synthesizers are difficult to source, heavy and prohibitively expensive. To assist beginners in keeping costs and barriers to entry low, I designed these 3D printed supports for wooden rails to be used with lasercut (and/or other) cases.
For decades (before eurorack was invented) modular synth cases were made with wooden rails permanently glued in, after some years of moving modules around, the wood would usually strip and deteriorate.
For this reason I have designed them so the wooden strips can be switched out with new ones if they need replacing.
The files include an .skp (sketchup) file if you wish to modify the design(post up a remix here). An .stl file of a single piece, and a .upp file of 12pieces to be used with 3DUP printers.
It is best to use a reasonably hard wood like Oak. Pine splits too easily. I recommend predrilling a small pilot hole before screwing in the screws for the first time to also limit splitting. The Oaks dimensions are 9mm x 9mm x the length of your case. The picture contains information about the Oak I use here in Australia from the hardware store Bunnings.
The bolt that goes through the case and into the support is M5 and secures to an encapsulating nut in the support. The picture shows how to place the nut in the support - nut point angled into the supports thick base plate then press down with your finger to lock the other side of the nut in. The picture shows the product I use from Bunnings. The nut you use may be a slightly different size. If it is too small, a little bit of glue to hold it in place should work. If the nut is too large then you will need to adjust the .skp or .stl file.
Sometimes I find the the bolt doesnt go through to the nut straight and locks the thread, this can be caused by the 5mm hole in the support(file it out a little) or the bolt itself isnt straight(unscrew and try again at a straighter angle).
This design is offered free for you to use for personal use only, a lot of my time has been put into producing it and I hope you enjoy using it.
Id love to see your pics and remixes put up here.
These designs are not for redistribution or resale.

For truly unique and crazy modules for your Synthesiser go to:
http://nonlinearcircuits.com/
http://nonlinearcircuits.blogspot.com

These feet are stencils that you can re-size and add your own designs, so that when you're out and about you can spray paint the ground you've walked. Mark your footsteps.

The initial inspiration came from sushi with laser cut designs that I saw on the unlimited design contest site. http://unlimiteddesigncontest.org/en/product/kimono-sushi Because sushi are so small it gave me the idea to create a stencil that could be small and portable. How did I create them? I will explain it to you so you can make your own and create your mark on all the places you've traveled near and far. The creation of the feet happens in illustrator. I used the pencil tool but if you prefer the pen that works just as well. These are best because you are drawing organic shapes. I literally held my feet in front of my computer and sketched them out on Illustrator.
You can either do that or use the ones I've made and adjust them as you see fit. The swirly designs were done using the eraser tool, I put them in after drawing the feet. I found it to be the best for additional designs because it makes a thick enough line to be visible when you spray paint your stencil. Several important things to make sure you do in Illustrator before using the laser cutter are the following: -You must have a border around the feet or else your stencil will be awkward and large.
-You have to make sure you have at least an inch between the border and your image or else you will have sloppy border lines painted on the ground.
-You are drawing an image based on the negative space, so make sure you're lines are outlining the image you want.
-The feet must be a single continuous line. If you put images inside the foot you have to attach the separate lines. Otherwise you'll just have a cut out of the design and it won't appear on your stencil.
-Save it as an SVG file.
-Lastly, if the laser cutter you're using is a smaller one make sure to rotate your image 90 degrees or else it will be too large and will not cut it. And that's just plain frustrating. Laser cutting! There are many possibilities for what materials to use.
The best ones I've found are: Plywood.
Plywood is super strong, but it's not as portable. You can't bend it and it could snap in half because you have to use thin plywood for the laser cutter to be able to cut through it.
It is heavy enough that you don't have to hold it when spray painting, which is a plus. Cardboard.
It's light and is portable as well. Though with too much folding or bending it could tear and it's not waterproof. Cardboard is best for tests instead of the final stencil.
It too is heavy enough to stay put when spray painting. Laser cutting!
The settings on the laser cutter were: Cardboard: Set the laser strength at 50 and speed at 70.
Plywood: Set the strength to the max of 100 and speed at 55. Make sure that you have the laser in focus or your stencil will not be accurate. Hit OK and let the laser work its magic! Now you have a lovely pair of feet to mark your travels with! Spray painting. Spray paint can be bought in hardware stores and comes in a wide range of colours. When you spray paint the feet hold the can 6 to 12 inches from your stencil. The closer you hold the can the stronger the paint which also means a higher chance of the paint running or going over the lines and ruining the image. Please note: Spray painting in public spaces is illegal in most countries so do it at night and be as conspicuous as possible. If that means dressing as a ninja, I highly encourage it. GOOD LUCK!

I made first the polar drawbot from daGHIZmo (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:798076). Thank you to him. But I modified gradually the pièces of the "chariot" to obtain a better way of working.
I give you now the final result of my reflexions :-))

The only pieces I don't modified are the hub, the rings (for arms) and the lockring which are originals from daGHIZmo's.
I have made also several other pieces for my polargraph and I share them here but they are not absolutely essential.

J'ai d'abord construit le Polar-drawbot de daGHIZmo (http: //www.thingiverse.com/thing:798076). Merci à lui. Mais j'ai modifié progressivement les pièces du "chariot" pour obtenir un fonctionnement meilleur.
Voici donc le résultat final de mes réflexions : -)

Les seules pièces que je ne fais pas modifiées sont le hub, les rings(pour des bras) et le lockring qui sont les originaux de daGHIZmo.
J'ai aussi fait trois autres pièces pour mon polargraph et je les partage ici mais elles ne sont pas absolument essentielles.

Printer:

Vertex K8400

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.15 mm

Infill:

from 30% to 60% selon les pièces

Notes:

Printed in PLA
Imprimé en PLA
Designed with FreeCad

assembly

For the bolts without nut, I tapped holes directly in the PLA at the right step of threading of the corresponding bolts.
The weights are made from several 20 mm steel washers (10g weight each).
For a better coherence of the set, glue together the two parts "porte_poids haut" et "porte_poids_bas" (black parts on the pictures) with cyanoacrylate glue.

Pour les boulons sans écrous, j'ai taraudé directement le PLA au pas de filetage des boulons correspondants.
Les poids sont fait de rondelles d'acier de 20mm de 10g chacune.
Pour une meilleure cohérence de l'ensemble, coller les deux pièces porte-poids (pièces noires sur les photos) ensemble à la cyanoacrylate.

description.text:

there are different parts version with holes in order to use springs with different diameters, the last two digits indicate the outer-inner diameter of the spring you want to use.

title: Passive attenuator
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a box which is taylor made for a resistive matching attenuator. Just mount two BNC connectors through the holes in the box and wire them with 3 resistors. There are many calculators out there which provide you with the values needed in order to give a specific attenuation and impedance.

As it is advisable to shield the attenuator you will also find a part which you can use as a gauge to draw the outline on a piece of copper sheet. This copper can be folded inside the box.

Typically the 3 resistors will be soldered to form a Pi-attenuator, but this really is up to you.

Finally the L-shaped lid has to be glued onto the box.

print_settings.Notes:: We had many problems with the abs but it seems that we are getting practice. What you see in the base is abs paste, made with acetone and abs leftovers. Anyway at the time of printing we throw some NELLY lacquer extra strong for the plate of scandal. I put the g-code so you can see other parameters.

description.text:
soporte para el filamento de la impresora 3dsteelpro de 3despana.com. Esta diseñado para incrustar dos rodamientos, el vástago se debe alargar hasta 12 cm, este tiene 10 cm. El rollo gira perfecto.
Los rodamientos están sacados de un fusor usado de una impresora laser. Si los que conseguís no tienen estas medidas adaptarlas.
Nos hemos dado cuenta que, o pegáis los rodamientos al soporte o imprimís la pieza que he añadido, encaja perfectamente. Como están hechas en abs, con la pasta de ABS (desechos abs y acetona pura), los hemos soldado y también hemos arreglado las imperfecciones de impresión. warping y craking debidos a la contracción del ABS.

Traducción google:

Support for the filament of the 3d steelpro printer from 3despana.com. It is designed to embed two bearings, the stem must be extended up to 12 cm, this has 10 cm. The roll turns perfect.
The bearings are drawn from a used fuser of a laser printer. If those who succeed do not have these measures to adapt them.
We have realized that, either you stick the bearings to the support or you print the piece that I added, it fits perfectly. As they are made in abs, with ABS paste (abs debris and pure acetone), we have soldered them and we have also fixed the printing imperfections. Warping and craking due to the contraction of ABS.

Printer:

3dprintsteelpro de 3despana.com

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,2

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Hemos tenido muchos problemas con el abs pero ya parece que vamos cogiendo practica. Lo que veis en la base es pasta de abs, hecha con acetona y sobras de abs. De todas formas a la hora de imprimir le echamos una poco de laca NELLY extrafuerte que para el pla va de escandalo. Os pongo el g-code para que veáis otros parámetros.

Traducción Google:

We had many problems with the abs but it seems that we are getting practice. What you see in the base is abs paste, made with acetone and abs leftovers. Anyway at the time of printing we throw some NELLY lacquer extra strong for the plate of scandal. I put the g-code so you can see other parameters.

title: Lasercut Hobby Workstation
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hobbyist/artist/modeller's painting workstation, which I designed for some friends and... so I wouldn't drop paint and glue all over my dining room table as well. Easily stores away in a closet too. Perfect for us city - small apartment dwellers. Includes hex and circle miniature bases as fillers within the frame design. Top shelf is intended for paint pots but easily stores your works in progress just as easily. Lower tier sidewalls are purposely designed to be tight. They will fit.

Formatted for cutting on 3mm MDF cut from 24" x 18" (Arch C sheet size) - which fits across the bed of an Epilog Helix. A 1/2 inch safety margin has been built into the design by default. I have provided the PDF and a SVG files that I converted online at https://cloudconvert.com/vsd-to-svg. Shared as is.

If you are inclined to be more than a taker and a consumer, pay forward by contributing to this site, as so many others have before you, or perform a random act of kindness, or donate to a good cause when the opportunity next arises. If you liked it enough to download it I'd appreciate a LIKE, it helps get the word out and spread these designs around. That is all.

description.text: as i am too cheap to buy a proper Lightblaster, I decided to modify the work of others. this is a work in progress. it is designed to print at 100% and fit any Canon fit lenses, and will accommodate a Yungnuo 56x series Flash. It has an integrated Manfrotto 200 type tripod mount, and is balanced so that a canon 24-105 lens and a Yongnuo 560 flash work well together. simply attach the lens to one side, fit the flash in the other, point it at your target (focus the lens properly), and fit a slide in the middle (you can use the slides provided, or design your own - one of them is designed to take a standard 35mm photographic slide for more effects). when the flash fires, the image from the middle will be displayed.

title: FPV Goggles for DJI with NVIDIA Shield K1. Eachine goggles 2 mod
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Eachine Goggles Two MOD + HDMI out of Nvidia Shield K1 + DJI DRONE (MAVIC PRO)

Eachine goggles Two:
http://www.banggood.com/Eachine-Goggles-Two-5-Inches-5_8G-40CH-Raceband-HD-1080p-HDMI-FPV-Goggles-Video-Glasses-p-1094862.html?rmmds=category
Optional Lenses: https://www.amazon.es/gp/product/B01M10NFSH/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

ENGLISH
If you use a DJI Mavic Pro or Phantom drone with the NVIDIA Shield K1 tablet you can use the HDMI output to connect FPV glasses. I use the components of Eachine Goggles Two (5” 1080p), except the case and the Wifi plate, to construct other glasses with:
1- Smaller size: From 220x160x120 to 125x143x76mm.
2- Option to add different lenses for people who have presbyopia.
The original distance between the lens and the screen is maintained.

05/18/2017: New version (V2):

  • New design with better adjustment to the face.
  • Reinforced tabs.
  • Increased ceiling thickness for more opacity.

11/23/2017. If you want a version with all the components use https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2664625

ESPAÑOL
Si usas un drone DJI Mavic Pro o Phantom con la tablet NVIDIA Shield K1 puedes usar la salida HDMI para conectar unas gafas FPV. Uso los componentes de las gafas FPV Eachine Goggles Two, excepto la carcasa y la placa Wifi, para construir otras gafas con:
1- Menor tamaño: De 220x160x120 a 125x143x76mm
2- Opción de añadir diferentes lentes para los que ya tenemos unos añitos y no vemos bien de cerca.
Se mantiene la distancia original entre la lente y la pantalla.

18/05/2017: Nueva versión (V2):

  • Nuevo diseño con mejor ajuste a la cara.
  • Pestañas reforzadas.
  • Aumentado el espesor del techo para mas opacidad.

23/11/2017. Si quieres una versión con todos los componentes utiliza el https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2664625

Mas info en: https://www.todophantom.com/foro/forum/para-todos/mavic/467592-gafas-fpv-modificadas-nvidia-shield-k1

Copyright (Safe creative): 1705182362982

Anet A6

Wires

3d printer

Hot glue gun

author: DeArtis

title: 2006 Chevy Cobalt Manual Transmission Shifter Retainer (Re-Design)

description.text: The shifter retainer is the most common piece to break in the shifter assembly of the Chevy Cobalt. If the locking teeth don't break due to the stress riser created at a rib joint near the base, the tooth notch wears out and the retainer slips out anyway. This re-design removes excess geometry and adds two mounting surfaces to place a set-screw. The teeth are now curved for flexibility - meaning that you are using the elastic coefficient of the plastic to provide locking force as well as the normal mechanisms of engagement.

description.text:
LOG:
17/05/2017 - Build completed and first flight (success)
10/03/2017 - First Documentation and Parts List
16/03/2017 - Added the first photos of the build process
22/03/2017 - Added a new version of the arms - now you can use other kind of landing gears for the arms (the original or this version: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:337881)

Thanks to MikeyB for his great design on Crossfire 2!

This is a work in progress.

This design is a combination of multiple remixes and other designs combined into one final work made by me. I'm a hobbyist, so have some patience with my designs (their aren't perfect!). I hope I can help someone!

All of this design parts can be replaced with the original parts from Crossfire 2, no problem.

If you liked this design and want to give me some motivation, please tip me to keep me working motivated. Maybe I'll make an instruction manual to help you guys out there! :)

Transmitter Flysky FS-I6 and FS Ia6B Receiver (http://www.banggood.com/FlySky-FS-i6-2_4G-6CH-AFHDS-RC-Transmitter-With-FS-iA6B-Receiver-p-983537.html?p=B313196470979201609S) (Note: I'm not using the fs ia6b in this model (I'm using the FS Ia10B), because I'm using it in other quadcopter - but you can use this receiver as well)

print_settings.Notes:: (2) The print was done with no infill & 2.4mm shell thickness.

description.text:
I searched online for round caps to sit on top of the exposed pointy knobs of my radiators, but could only find angular ones which were also rather unattractive. So I decided to make them myself.

The design is very minimalistic and requires only a rubber washer to secure the cap onto the radiator knob (see post-printing for details).

Since I don't own a printer (yet :-), I had the excellent Crash from 3D Hubs (https://www.3dhubs.com/service/kresimir) print the caps for me on his Ultimaker. On his good advice, we used Colorfabb Copolyester HT (http://ht.colorfabb.com/) to make sure the caps can withstand the radiators' high temperatures.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker Original

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

100

Infill:

None (hollow)

Notes:

(1) As the caps sit on top of hot radiator knobs, they were printed with Colorfabb Copolyester HT for high thermal stability and durability.

NB Make sure that the filament you use can withstand your radiator's max temperatures!

(2) The print was done with no infill & 2.4mm shell thickness.

After printing the cap, insert a thick rubber washer (20mm Outer Diameter, 6mm Hole Diameter, 4-6mm Thickness), and then push-fit the cap onto the radiator knob. If you use a washer of the above dimensions, there's no need to use glue.

For the initial design, I used Google SketchUp with the dimensions scaled up x100.
I then used OpenScad to scale the model back to actual size and verify the design.
Clamp on fan wasn't wide enough to clamp on the cubicle wall.

title: garmin gopro handlebar_clamp_31.8(customizable) component
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
2017/03/17 update
garmin_gopro_318clamp_v2.FCStd is FreeCAD (https://www.freecadweb.org/) project file.
it's an OpenSource 3D CAD.

My original design is for 31.8mm handlebar with M4x16 screw, you can easy customize by editing "bikeClamp" & "screwSet" spreadsheet in FreeCAD.
ex, 26mm + M5 screw. etc...

a_318_clamp_with_hinge_v2.stl
: use spreadsheet to customize clamp & screw size

b_gopro_mount_v2.stl
: shrink center fin for more loose

c_garmin_edge_mount_v2.stl
: dig a hole for garmin edge 800 temperature sensor

=============================================================
2017/03/09 initial post
I want to design a garmin + gopro mount on my 31.8mm bicycle handlebar.
but I fail on strength design(junction broken) when I do road test.
so I have given up this design, and buy a commercial one.
I am no longer working on it.
those basic component working fine, I would like to share that you can take and remix it.

I use 0.2mm layer height, 80%infill, PLA, try your own setting.

a_318_clamp_with_hinge.stl
: use one M4 screw with nut

b_gopro_mount.stl
: the base plate is 18x18x2mm
: BTW, my action cam is SJ9000, I think should work on gopro too.

c_garmin_edge_mount.stl
: the outer ring radius is 18mm, height is 4.5mm

comments.text: Who needs all these sockets ???? :-)
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
At work I bought a full set from craftsman and they came in bags.
Since I work at a 3d printing company, I get to design/make things for free and drew this up to just to keep them organized for quick use.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: OK, I bet it includes these old fashioned fractional inch sockets US mechanics use to round the head of metric bolts and the other way around :-)
comments.author: Bobo316_1

comments.text: rounding heads comes down to the user, you can round a fastener with a 6 point just as easy.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
You have more chance of rounding with a 12 points and good luck with a 12 points with a damaged nut, even more if you use inch sockets on metric ! Same for bolts plenty of damaged threads seized bolts because of mixing metric and inch. Typical in US shops I noticed.
Do they design in "inch" in your company ? Which one ? If yes, better to avoid this brand ! Non standard and therefore expensive, hard to find spares plus many other issues.

remixed_from.title: Anet A8 e3d v6 Bowden Print Carriage Redux

title: Anet A8 e3d v6 Bowden Print Carriage Redux Remix for CloneE3D

description.text: This is a remix I did cause the original one is a bit too tight for use with E3D v6 Clones so I widened the mounting hole for the hotend. I alse made the bearing mounting holes a bit elongated since my printers X-rods was a bit too close together to slide without friction. This makes it easier to tighten the screws for the bearings without putting stress on the rods if they are wider or closer together. Props to the original creator for making such an awesome carriage!

Anet A8

Rafts:

Yes

70%
